title: Morrison in talks with Takeover Panel over competing offers
text:
Wm Morrison has called on the Takeover Panel to break the deadlock between the US private equity funds jostling to buy the supermarket.

Morrison is in talks with the Panel to launch a formal auction process, having last month agreed a £7bn offer from Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. A rival consortium led by SoftBank-owned Fortress Investment Group could still trump CD&R's bid, with neither firm having declared their offers final.

The auction is likely to take place prior to shareholder meetings scheduled for the week of October 18. Shareholders will receive further details of the CD&R offer later this month to provide “sufficient time” to resolve the situation, Morrison said.

Briefly

Engineer Smiths Group has agreed to sell its medial division to ICU Medical for $2.4bn after the US-based group outbid private equity firm TA Associates. Smiths said it had withdrawn its recommendation of the bid from TA, which had last month agreed a $2bn deal. ICU's superior offer involves initial cash proceeds of $1.85bn and equity worth $500m based on Tuesday's closing price, Smiths said. It expects the sale to close in the first half of 2022.

Online gambling company 888 has confirmed it is in talks to buy the betting shops and European business of William Hill, the UK bookmaker that was taken private in a £2.9bn deal last year. London-listed 888 said it was in “advanced discussions” with Caesars Entertainment, William Hill's new owner.

Halfords said trading in recent months has remained strong, with sales in the 20-week period to mid August up 18.7 per cent versus the equivalent pre-pandemic period. The bike and auto parts retailer said that in spite of a challenging operating environment it continued to target a full-year pre-tax profit of at least £75m.

Martin Sorrell's S4 Capital said its Media Monks division will merge with Cashmere, a US-based culture and creative marketing agency. Terms of the deal were not provided.

Bakkavor left full-year guidance unchanged after cost savings helped deliver a 63.8 per cent surge in half-year underlying earnings. The ready meal and convenience foodmaker reported an adjusted operating profit of £47m on revenue up 4 per cent to £915.7m. “Despite unprecedented challenges in labour availability and its impact on the supply chain, as well as raw material inflation, the group expects to deliver full-year operating profit margin in line with the first half,” it said.

Biffa, the waste disposal group, said trading in the first half ending September has continued in line with the board's expectations.

Retailer Dunelm said recent sales growth has been encouraging and better than anticipated. In the absence of any further trading restrictions, 2022 pre-tax profit will be modestly ahead of analysts' expectations, it said. For the full year ended June, Dunelm reported a £157.8m pre-tax profit on sales of £1.3bn, up 44.6 per cent and 26.3 per cent respectively. Having not paid a 2020 dividend the company declared a one-off payment of 65p per share in addition to its 35p full-year ordinary dividend.

Avon Protection said it had secured a contract worth up to $87.6m to develop and supply a helmet for the US Army. The new contract replaces one announced in September 2020 which was withdrawn following a competitor protest.

Video games maker Frontier Developments said it was on track to release flagship title Jurassic World Evolution 2 in November to catch holiday season sales. For the full year ended May Frontier posted operating profit up 20 per cent to £19.9m on revenue up 19 per cent to £90.7m.

Winkworth, the London-focused estate agent, said first half pre-tax profit jumped 330 per cent to £2m as revenues more than doubled to £5.3m. Sales applicants continue to track well ahead of 2019 levels and the rental market has seen a significant upturn in activity, it said.

Beyond the Square Mile

El Salvador's pioneering adoption of bitcoin as legal tender hit snags within hours of the launch after the government had to take its app for storing the volatile digital asset temporarily offline and the global price slumped. 

Doug Field, an executive with responsibility for Apple's secretive car project, has left for Ford in an exit that potentially spells the end of the iPhone maker's automotive ambitions.

PayPal, the US online payments company, has agreed to acquire Paidy, a Tokyo-based “buy now, pay later” group, for ¥300bn ($2.7bn).

Essential comment before you go

Helen Thomas
The UK's target to raise £12bn a year for NHS funding plays on the misplaced idea among voters that national insurance exclusively funds “good” spending on healthcare. National insurance, though, is a tax on activity which could fall hardest on those labour-intensive sectors worst hit by the pandemic.

Peggy Hollinger
Germany and France have stepped up support for their aerospace manufacturing industries with hydrogen and hybrid electric flight as priorities. But while Britain has provided £8.5bn to the sector through its general loan scheme and export finance, there was no obvious industrial plan guiding how the money was allocated. And without a long-term strategy, there is a very real risk that British aerospace falls even further behind.
